data.title: No intellisense on 'Case-sensitive Journaled HFS+' volumes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Osx 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. create a new image with `hdiutil create -type SPARSE -fs 'Case-sensitive Journaled HFS+' IMAGENAME` and mount it
2. create/copy a typescript project in it

Mac OS Extended (Journaled) images work just fine.
I use a case-sensitive image to deal with the issues with git and renaming files.

data.title: In Breakpoints, cursor indicates click-ability where not actually clickable
data.body:
- VSCode Version: All (up to 1.4.0)
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run debug task
2. Click on an any options in the "Breakpoints" but _not_ on the checkbox.

The cursor is changed to a "pointer" (to use the CSS term) for the entire line in the breakpoints, but the only thing that is actually clickable is the checkbox. This is extremely annoying! Please make the entire line clickable or at least only show the pointer where is actually **is** clickable. But the former is preferable.

data.title: Clicking code action in "F8" popup doesn't refresh code fix actions/close dialog = possibility of duplicate actions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: Windows 10

I've implemented a code fix provider but hit a bit of a snag. Assume the following code:

``` dart
myFunc() {
  myFun(); // <-- Typo
}
```

I get a code fix here that says "change `myFun()` to `myFunc()`" and provides an edit which inserts a `c` at the correct position.

If I click the lightbulb and apply it, everything is fine; the change is applied, the menu closes.

However, if I hit `F8` and click the link in the popup:

![Code action](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1078012/17945949/fc2471d8-6a3d-11e6-9b03-2b1f97230121.png)

The edit is applied (I'm doing this via `workspace.applyEdit()` in a command) but the link remains on the screen. This means you can click it a second time and it inserts a second `c` (and a third...).

Now, I could keep track of this by mutating the source edit object and refusing to apply it a second time; but it seems to me that Code should do something here; either re-request code-fixes for this location or close the popup when it's applied?

(It's possible it already should do something like this and I've implemented something incorrectly; but I've been struggling to find it, and I can't find any good examples of others that have already implemented this properly to step through).

data.title: Fix Contributing link
Quick file find, or jump to file in explorer by typing filename
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

We are literally working with thousands of files. Currently the user is limited to a mouse scrolling through a large folder structure to find the file and manually selecting the file.

We kindly request that finding files in the Explorer be easier. The Windows Explorer is a parallel example.

For example, provide a box where you can start typing in the file name and the Explorer is limited to showing files that match. Please support wild cards.

For example, allow typing in the Explorer to jump to a file.

data.title: Closing file open in 2 places opens "save" dialog
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a project in VS Code
2. Split the editor so 2 files can be viewed side by side
3. Open the same file twice and arrange so both are visible
4. Make an edit to the file (either one - the changes should sync between the two views)
5. Try closing one of the instances of the file

**Desired behavior:** The file will close with no prompt, since there is another instance of the file still being edited
**Current behavior:** The file will prompt you to save. Not only that, if you click "Don't Save", the file will revert to the version on disk, and any work done on the file will disappear from the instance still open.

data.title: ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(217)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0
- OS Version: Raspbian GNU/Linux 8.0 (jessie)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. I installed  VS code on raspberry pi
2. When I tried run it. so following error happened.
3.  I've tried this way : [Linux SUID Sandbox Development](https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/linux_suid_sandbox_development.md)

Run following line.
pi@KERNEL_BZ:/usr/lib/chromium-browser $ ls
chrome-sandbox
pi@KERNEL_BZ:sudo mkdir /usr/local/sbin/chrome-devel-sandbox
pi@KERNEL_BZ:cp chrome-sandbox /usr/local/sbin/chrome-devel-sandbox
pi@KERNEL_BZ:sudo chown root:root /usr/local/sbin/chrome-devel-sandox
pi@KERNEL_BZ:shdo chmod 4775 /usr/local/sbin/chrome-devel-sandbox

Put this line in may ~/.bashrc
export CHMOE_DEVEL_SANDBOX=/usr/local/sbin/chrome-devel-sandbox

I've tried to fix but I couldn't fix this error.
Please review my error and fix it.

Thanks,
Felinus Jeong

pi@KERNEL_BZ:~/Development/vscode/scripts $ ./code.sh 
[2396:0825/023731:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(217)] Running without the SUID sandbox! See https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/linux_suid_sandbox_development.md for more information on developing with the sandbox on.

data.title: file explorer mouse/keyboard handling
data.body:
Within the File Explorer, 
when using mouse button, it would be nice to extend with following functionality:
- single click (replaces the file with the clicked one in current tab)
  -- double click (opens file but now as an extra tab)
  using the keyboard 
- default behavior of enter key is now to rename a file (should be configurable in settings) 
- it would be nice to be able to open the selected file in a current tab with a configurable key config (like command - enter) op to be opened in new tab (by shift-command-enter likewise)

data.title: UI flicker on Save, with some fun side effects
data.body:
this was discussed a little in [https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7322] but it was closed b/c of non-response  ( @bpasero )

[Here's a screencast](https://youtu.be/3lnbWsz4KeU) of the buggy behavior

[Here's a diff't screencast](https://youtu.be/FTzFv1GyTPo) of similar actions in the same file that don't reproduce the bug
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. clone [this repo](https://github.com/davezuko/react-redux-starter-kit) (no need to `npm install`). bug happens in my project and others as well (all `JavaScript/Node` projects), but using this repo makes replication easier.
2. open the folder in `VS Code`
3. open `.babelrc` in a tab
4. open `package.json` in another tab
5. delete a line from the `dependencies` prop in `package.json`
6. `ctrl+s` (or whatever on a mac)

**you should observe some flickering in a number of places in the UI**
1. close `package.json` tab, confirm `save` in the ensuing dialogue

**the tab should close, but the text of `package.json` should paste-over the text in your other open file, ie, `babelrc`**

This behavior also happens often when editing VS Code `settings` JSONs. 

**my settings**: 

```
$ code --list-extensions
EditorConfig.EditorConfig
Nuuf.theme-hackershaze
Shan.code-settings-sync
TsumiNa.Seti-theme

dbaeumer.vscode-eslint
donjayamanne.githistory
dzannotti.vscode-babel-coloring
flowtype.flow-for-vscode
gerane.Theme-AnarchistEighties
gerane.Theme-Batman
gerane.Theme-FocusLight

gerane.Theme-Zenburn
gerane.Theme-sublimexoria
joelday.docthis
lonefy.vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter

msjsdiag.debugger-for-chrome
nemesv.copy-file-name
robertohuertasm.vscode-icons
seanmcbreen.MDTools
slevesque.vscode-multiclip
tnaseem.theme-seti
xabikos.JavaScriptSnippets
xabikos.ReactSnippets
zhuangtongfa.Material-theme

```

```
// these are 'user settings', 'workplace settings' file is empty
{
    "files.associations": {
        "*.js": "javascriptreact"
    },
    "editor.acceptSuggestionOnEnter": false,
    "editor.mouseWheelZoom": true,

}
```

data.title: How do I provide user input via console while debugging a Node app?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.3

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Simple Node script that uses [prompt](https://github.com/flatiron/prompt).
2. Run app via debugger.

**Expected result**: Prompt waits for user input, accepting it via the debug console.
**Actual result**: Prompt waits for user input, but does not accept input via the debug console.

Am I missing something here, or is this just not possible with Code yet?

data.title: Pasting Large Amounts of Text to Terminal Doesn't Work

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:45:31.680Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601

I find that when I'm copy/pasting a chunk of text from an editor window that the paste command stops working when I reach some arbitrary, variably large size.  Usually a few thousand characters of text will trigger the bug.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code and an integrated terminal (in my case, PowerShell, but the same issue exists in cmd.exe)
2. Create a large block of text.  I don't believe the format of the text matters at all
3. Paste the text in the terminal below and it will fail to paste when your text selection gets large enough.  I can typically trigger the issue after a few thousand characters.

I know that the text is in the clipboard because I can paste it outside to Notepad as well as to another editor tab inside of VSCode.  The issue only exists when pasting to the terminal.

data.title: Problem to copy content of a opened file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In "Open Editors", open two different files with some content
2. Choose one of the two files to open in editor
3. When it's open, click and open the other file, and press "Ctrl + a" and, after that, try to copy by pressing "Ctrl + c"
4. Open the first file again, and try to paste the content. The clipboard contains content before the "new copy".

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16581931/17931474/069751a0-69e2-11e6-963a-1632d2ab3c5a.png)

Ps.: Observe when you press "Ctrl + a", the "lines numbers" are selected too.

data.title: File closes when network drive goes away

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:41:29.513Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 14.5.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Connect to a network drive using SMB or AFP
2.Open a file on one of those drives in VSCode
3.Disconnect the drive.
4.VSCode crashes

Sublime does NOT behave this way. 

Here's why it is a problem... I'm working on a set of files on a network drive. I move my laptop to a different location, or switch from wired to wireless. The network drive disconnects. Now, I lose all the files I was working on and have to re-open them all. 

Another example...  I'm working on 10+ files at the end of the day and I close my laptop and go home. The next morning I come in, and I have to re-open all 10 of those files (assuming I remember what they were).

Correct behavior should be to keep the file open.  Of course, you can't save it until you reconnect the network drives, but at least it is there.  This is how Sublime works.

data.title: Regex find with line start matches mid-line on "find next"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open/create a document containing a line with multiple characters except `{`
   1. alternatively, just fill the line with a bunch of `a`s
2. Search for `^[^{]`. The first character of the matching line is selected, as expected, with the find box stating something like "1 of 338"
   1. or `^a`, if you went with 1.i
3. Find next. Instead of going to the next matching line, the next character on the current line is selected, with the find box stating "? of 338"
4. Find previous works as expected

It seems as if the search is run on the substring starting after the current match; but the beginning of this substring is erroneously interpreted as "start of line".

A symmetric issue occurs with `a$` and find previous.

For the moment, my workaround is searching for `^[^{].*$`
